childhood cancer organizations co-executive director Jay Scott so thank
you for having me here today it's it's nice to talk to all of you I'm gonna talk to you a little bit today a little
bit about data but more about what drove us to get into data so my name is Jay
and let's see this is not a border here
I think I never used slides so I'm gonna go without him because it's not really
working so my daughter for those of you that know of Alex's Lemonade my daughter
is Alex she was our second child and she started developing symptoms when she was
just a baby and she was diagnosed with cancer at one neuroblastoma was the name of the cancer and we lived in New
England at the time we went to Boston for a second opinion we went to New York City for a third opinion and all of the
doctors differed on how we should treat her and so my wife and I were in our 20s at the time and we had to decide how to
treat this child that had very serious deadly cancer after a couple of years of
of treatment at our hospital in Connecticut all three of those hospitals agreed on how we should treat her and
that was that we should stop treating her because she didn't have a chance at surviving her cancer and that we should
take her home and let her spend her few remaining days out of the hospital we
weren't willing to accept that and one doctor from New York kind of pulled me aside on my last visit there and he said
listen I think if you guys are willing to make a trip to Philadelphia I think there's a doctor there that could help
you and so our first trip to Philadelphia Alex was three she was almost four and
she was in so much pain from the cancer which was as high as her neck and as low as the bones in her left foot she was on
morphine 24 hours a day and um we went down there and it was really scary for
her and it was scary for us because she was getting the first experimental treatment that she ever got in her life
in this experimental treat required her to be in isolation in a LED
room so the walls were made of LED the ceiling and floor were made of lead one parent was allowed in a time allowed in
at a time but you had to wear a radiation meter and then she had to be in bed behind a lead shield and so they
injected her with a liquid it was called radioactive iodine and it went through
her bloodstream and this liquid radiated her neuroblastoma from the inside out we
didn't know it at the time but she received the highest dose that a human has ever received of that treatment and so she had to stay in that room in
isolation until she was no longer radioactive it took three days and when
we were leaving the hospital something amazing happened she told us the
treatment worked my wife said what do you mean the treatment worked she said I could tell by the way I feel and then she said she
wanted to go shopping for a Christmas dress it was right after Thanksgiving and so we took her shopping for a Christmas dress we took her home but we
took home a kid that was a completely different kid than the one that we brought into the hospital three days earlier we went back to Connecticut a
couple weeks later they did an MRI of her and the doctor in Connecticut said wow that treatment worked and we said
what do you mean the treatment worked he said all of the cancer is gone except from one spot on her spine it's gone in
her foot it's gone in her neck it's gone in her abdomen there's just one spot on her spine left so they said we're
willing to treat her again we want to give her a transplant we want to give her stem-cell transplant so the day
after her fourth birthday she went into the hospital for a one-month stay to get a stem cell transplant stem cell
transplants like a bone-marrow transplant except they take your own cells out and they put them back into you after they give you a lot of chemotherapy and it was while she was in
the hospital getting that transplant she just said one day when I get out of hospital I want to set up a lemonade
stand and we said it's January
we live in Connecticut no one's gonna buy lemonade and we I think much about it she got out of the hospital and then
she kept asking us about setting up a lemonade stand first it was like once a
month then it was once a week then it was every day and my wife said to her Alex what do you want to buy cuz we'll
just buy it for you we'll buy you the toy you don't need to set up a lemonade stand and she said oh
I don't want to keep the money I want to give it to the doctors so they can come up with treatments like the one I got in Philadelphia so the treatment has such a
profound impact on the way she felt she thought she could do something to help those doctors and in our house we like
to tease each other so we teased her that she was gonna bring in five or ten dollars and tell them to cure cancer but
that was the first sign that Alex was filling a gap that she saw she saw that there was a need for more treatments
better treatments because she had friends from the hospital that were constantly dying and she thought she could do something with her Lemonade
Stand so we let her set up the lemonade stand in the front yard and she did
$2,000 that first day that's the lemonade stand right there
she had her little little tykes table you know kids cash register and a
pitcher of lemonade I had to run out to the store about five times to get more lemonade because people kept coming it
was amazing some of them came with smiles some of them came with tears everybody had a story there was one guy
who gave her a card and when she opened the card there was $100 in there and
there was a note that said Alex your parents sure must be proud of you because I know that I am we never knew
what that guy story was but for him not to know her and to drop off $100 I'm sure that he had a story when we asked
Alex about it she said it was the best thing that ever happened to her that day she was so excited she got her clothes
out the night before she had her Cheerios on the table because she want to make sure she got out there early you know she her advertisement said she was
opening at 11:00 she got out there at 6:30 in the morning we thought that was
a one-time thing we delivered the money to the hospital and we went about our lives ALX continued to fight cancer cuz the
transplant didn't work she still had that spot on her spine and um the
doctors in Philadelphia told us listen if you guys could spend more time here we have more treatment options for her
so we moved we moved down to Philly it's about 250 miles which in the Northeast
is quite far around around in the West you guys drive a lot farther but we had
to go through Connecticut traffic New York city traffic New Jersey traffic and Philadelphia traffic to get there the
longest it ever took us was 14 hours so we moved and when we got to Philadelphia
Alex said she wanted to set up a lemonade stand again and we said Alex we
don't know what he buddy and she said but I want to set it up so we made her wait until the fall when the kids went
to school and it was a cold fall day and you see her there with a winter hat and
mittens on she did 800 bucks and she wasn't happy because we made her wait
till it was cold out and we told her that nobody wanted lemonade when it was cold eight hundred dollars still pretty good
lemonade stand but not for her next year came around to start to get warm she said I want to do lemonade stand again
and so my wife sent home a flyer with the school with the classes they would
send home Flyers on Thursday and one of the one of the other parents called the newspaper and the Philadelphia Inquirer
did a full page article so before she even opened for business she had over 2,000 cause she raised 12,000 bucks in
one day caused a traffic jam in our neighborhood the police came by they said if she's gonna have a lemonade
stand again can you guys tell us we gave the money to the hospital next
year came around she said I want to set up the lemonade stand again and we thought there's no way that she can beat 12,000 and it poured rain on the day she
had her lemonade stand and um she did 18,000 in the pouring rain and it was at
that lemonade stand we realized something special was happening because people came from all over Pittsburgh
Virginia New York and they stood out in the rain and washed what was happening because so many people were coming I
mean you you bring in 18,000 and eliminate stand you're selling a lot of cups of lemonade
and so I'll remember all during his time she's still fighting her cancer and so
she was doing she would get calls from reporters often and we would always tell her cuz she was like uh she was like a
grandma you know she was like a grown-up in a kid's body because she all she did was deal with adults all the time in the
hospital and so when reporters would call we'd say Alex there's a reporter on the phone do you want to talk to them and what she'd say where they calling
from and we would tell her and if she didn't recognize the town or the newspaper she would say tell him I'm not
feeling well but if she did she would get on the phone and so a big magazine
called for her and my wife and I don't remember what it was it was either Good Housekeeping or Family Circle and we
said Alex there's a reporter that wants to talk to you and she said okay and so
I'm on the call my wife was listening in
and Alex told the reporter well last year my goal was to raise $100,000 and I did that with the help of other people
so this year I'm gonna raise a million dollars with my lemonade stand and so we
were like Alex you can't tell a reporter that and she said but I think if people
continue to help me I think I can do it and around that time we started really
thinking about what the money was doing and what other gaps could we fill and we didn't care if something was was fancy
we didn't care if it was glamorous and so one thing that we noticed was a lot of Alex's friends from the hospital
would die waiting for their clinical trial to open up and so we talked to the
doctors and we said what's the problem they said the problem is we don't have enough staff and what they meant by
staff was they have a treatment and they have a patient but they don't have the staff to do all the paperwork to get
that treatment to the patient and so we hired a nurse practitioner with $60,000 from that year to work halftime
enrolling patients and they tripled the number of patients getting into the clinical trials with one half-time person it's not a glamorous position but
it filled the gap and it made a difference and so her million-dollar goal the word got out she was on Oprah
she was on The Today Show in thousands and thousands of people joined together to help her with by
setting up lemonade stands all over the world a couple of weeks after that stand
we got a call from one of her supporters and it was Volvo cars they were big fans
of hers and they said how's Alex doing it we said she's not doing well the cancer has really taken over her body they said how about the
million-dollar goal and we said she's at 700,000 and they said tell her we're
gonna take over a million so we told her would that she reached a million she
clapped once and she said the next goal is a gazillion her older brother told
her that wasn't a real number and she said I know that so she died a couple weeks after that she was holding out to
hit that million dollars we thought that was the end of the lemonade stand but it
was just the beginning because the outpouring from people after she died was even greater than when she was alive
that year another two million dollars came in after she died if you fast
forward to today 175 million has been raised actually after last night 176
thank you but that doesn't matter if the money's
not making a difference right you can have a billion dollars if it's not making a difference it doesn't matter

whether it's bench research translational research or clinical

happy with the progress because of these kids here and kids like this these five
kids had cancers including Alex that have zero percent chance of survival and
so we needed to find new gaps we needed to find new ways to approach their
cancers and that's where my wife and I we would talk we we live and we breathe
childhood cancer it's our life now to cure childhood cancer and so we were looking for

head of impact computing for Amazon Web Services Erica Valbuena hi everyone je
thank you very much for sharing your story and when I was preparing for today I did not imagine being so emotional
having to walk up on the stage hearing that story so thank you for having me
I'm Erica Murdoch Valbuena and I'm the head of impact computing and before we bring Jay and Casey back up on stage I
wanted to share a bit more about the business that I run that helps support a lot of you here in this room and some of
our customers so impact computing enables our customers to solve the
biggest global challenges at scale with AWS and these are challenges like curing
cancer or mapping the world's water supply or feeding global populations or
giving financial access to the unbanked and I joined AWS
because I've worked for a long time with with nonprofits and technology and for
people like Jay and Alex because I believe that the pace of innovation and change that's happening in the space of
technology deserves to be put in the hands of the people that are closest to the problem and we want to democratize
access to that technology and so we are a focused team here with an AWS that
empowers the world's leading organizations to build those breakthrough solutions that can help
drive change faster and we work across the commercial and the public sector to
ensure that you all have the tools that you need to do that work and so that seem near limitless compute power that
Nasdaq or lyft or Netflix has it their fingertips belongs at the fingertips of
each of you and we want to make sure you get it and in fact if you were to open your computer right now and set up an
AWS account you would have a million computers at your disposal and so our job is to unlock that power and I want
to take you on a journey to three different places around the world today as I explained through the eyes of our customer what this means
so by 2050 the world must feed nine billion people and rice is a staple food
source for many of those folks in fact it accounts per twenty four twenty percent of the calories per capita
globally and in the next ten years rice crop yields have to increase by 25
percent and so we need to ensure the viability and strength of that genome so
that is the climate changes we are able to keep up with the growing demand founded in 1960 and located in the
Philippines the International Rice Research Institute develops rice varieties that can withstand drought
flooding disease and other effects of climate change and they a few years ago decided to lead
an international effort to sequence the rice genome to help solve this big global problem and so they took 3,000
varieties from 89 different countries and they put it onto AWS and this data
they used 30 7,000 compute cores in a situ and over
two days they were able to compute all this data which may sound like a lot of numbers but it was over 200 times faster
than they would have been able to do had they put this have they done this in their local computing environment and so
now Erie and other scientists that tackle genomic data around feeding the
planet can develop rice varieties that are climate smart and can withstand whatever comes their way and so if
you're an organization that has massive data workloads or maybe you even think that you do and you want to get more
insight and information out of it we can help you do that and in fact if it's something you want to do over and over
again we can also help you do that well let's travel over to South Africa so 1
million species as the National Geographic reported earlier this year our risk of extinction and as many of us
in this room know our survival is in direct correlation with ensuring our
planets biodiversity and South Africa is home to some of the most diverse
ecosystems on the planet and to help save this ecosystem
a man named Paul developed Africa to bring wildlife from the savanna into
your living room or your laptop and so Africa has put free 24-hour live streams
online from 6 permanent remote locations remote watering holes across many
different game reserves in the country but they didn't just want to provide this live stream for folks to leverage
they wanted to take it a step further and be able to identify the animals and help keep track of them so they're so
using AWS as machine learning they're able to identify the sound or the song of a bird or a particular giraffe that
shows up or a particular Rhino and in fact unfortunately one Rhino was killed
by poachers and it was a mother rhino and the baby was standing next to and it was left to be on its own and thousands
of people actually turned in to the live stream and they were able to save raised $13,000 to help ensure that this rhino
lived on to adulthood and was thriving and again African wants to do as much as
they can with this video footage that they're collecting and so they want to
also predict nighttime behavior because in times of drought and to help with anti-poaching efforts this machine
learning that's layered on top of their video can help keep track of those animals and so if you're looking to gain
more insights from your visual or video data we can help you do that as we have
one of the broadest and deepest sets of machine learning or if you're looking to operate in the remote far-off places of
the world we can also help you build a reliable solution that gets you the answers that you need and then I want to
take us one more place over to Cambodia so Cambodia is the eighth most disaster
vulnerable country in the world with 75% of the country living in flood plains
and after one such event they experience a lot of typhoons and flooding and
natural hazards and droughts but after one such fled 36 percent of Cambodians
received zero alert about the impending flood and 72 percent of Cambodians
received an alert too late to take any action and so people in need a check NGO
developed two solutions on top of Amazon Web Services the first of which was
sending early warning signs so it's a voice recorded message that gets blasted out to the subscribers there are
currently four hundred thousand of them that warns them about an impending natural disaster and the second thing
that they built was a solar-powered stream gage that's built on top of open source technology to measure water
height so when it gets to a predetermined dangerous level that they're able to send a notification and
let people take action and we aided them not only in their ability to acquire
data center resources but also the ability to grow and scale as they obtain
more subscribers because the government eventually wants everyone in the country to be on this to be able to receive
notifications they also have a reliable solution in us that operates during the most crucial of
times and this data also is going to help the Cambodian government be proactive and forecast and predict
future events so that they can ensure that their citizens are safe when this occurs so we've talked about three
